The main event in the post is "I became serious with out any sign of change and now I don't care about anything." This event is significant because it marks a shift in the individual's personality and behavior, from being outgoing and charismatic to becoming detached and uninterested in things. The event may have been triggered by various factors such as suppression of one's true self due to external expectations or other traumatic events.

Event: Starting a WhatsApp groupchat to support and talk about daily struggles with depression.
Post: "I'm so glad I'm not alone in this struggle. It's comforting to know that others understand what it's like to live with depression. Let's support each other and lift each other up! #depression #mentalhealth #supportgroup"

Event: Losing almost all feelings and being unable to cry anymore, resulting in panic attacks.
Post: "I've become a shell of my former self, incapable of feeling any emotions. I used to be so sensitive and empathetic, but now I feel like a robot going through the motions. Even when something terrible happens, I can't muster up any tears. It's like my well of emotions has run dry. Instead of feeling sad or upset, I just feel numb. And to make matters worse, I've started having panic attacks out of nowhere. My heart races, and my mind goes blank. It's like I'm trapped in a never-ending nightmare. I don't know what's happening to me, but I know I need help."

Event: Relapse into depression after feeling better and making positive changes in one's life.
Post: "I thought I had finally kicked depression to the curb, but it turns out I'm just naturally prone to it. Despite all the positive changes I've made in my life, I still can't seem to shake it off."

Event: Talking about depression with people
Post:
"I'm so tired of feeling like I'm stuck in this rut. No matter what I do, I just can't seem to shake off this depression. It's like it's a part of me, something that I'll never be able to escape. #depression #mentalhealth #stuck"

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of the person's depression to their inherent nature or character, rather than to external factors. By saying "it's like it's a part of me," the person is implying that their depression is a chronic and long-lasting condition that they are unable to change or control.

Post:
"I'm so useless, I can't even get anything right."

Explanation: This sentence is an example of a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of the event (not being able to get things right) to a stable and long-lasting trait of the person (being inherently useless). It implies that the person's inability to succeed is due to their natural incompetence, rather than any external factors or temporary circumstances.

This post attributes the cause of the individual's struggles with negative thinking patterns and suicidal thoughts to their natural disposition. It implies that the individual is prone to such thoughts and that they are a stable part of their personality, rather than considering external factors or circumstances that may have contributed to their feelings.

Event: Thinking about killing oneself, specifically feeling scared to act on those thoughts.
Post:
"I'm constantly battling suicidal thoughts because I'm inherently weak and can't handle life's challenges."

It is important to note that the SAS attribution style can be harmful and reinforce negative self-talk. It is essential to recognize that thoughts and behaviors are not fixed and can change with effort and support. If you or someone you know is struggling with suicidal thoughts, it is important to seek professional help and support.
